2) Can you separate (at least partially) a solution using gravity/centripetal force? (e.g. salt water would have high salinity at the bottom, low at the top)
3) Can you actually precipitate out a salt if the gravity/force is high enough?

I work with centrifuges every day. We find that we have better luck with plastic centrifuge cones. My question is how many RPMs does the centrifuge get up too? I do have another one it’s a 16 well centrifuge that goes up to 3750 RPMs also uses a 50 ml centrifuge cone. Most of the stuff we spin has to be spun for at least 15 minutes.

Random fun fact I read an article a couple of years ago about how in  3rd world countries it's hard to get a real centrifuge(cost) but it's very needed for diagnosis of illness like malaria and other things. So somebody a doctor I think got frustrated and came up with an cheap centrifuge made of string and paper and powered by your arms that works just as well as the big expensive electric ones.

First off upgrade from glass vials to plastic ones. (I know it sounds like a downgrade, but its durability in the spin cycle that is the upgrade. Less likely if not will not break.) Then lets start seperating some interesting things Like Gallium, glue, syrup(Chocolate/maple/ect), slime, and for fun of it our favorite starch mixture Oobleck! You can also try some other odd items that are slime/gel-like. including hairgel, shampoo, conditioner, a combo of bodywash and those two... and more.
